etymologies: Old English thrǣd (noun), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch draad and German Draht, also to the verb throw. The verb dates from late Middle English

definitions: a long, thin strand of cotton, nylon, or other fibers used in sewing or weaving

examples.text: he had a loose thread on his shirt
the thread that bound them had snapped

shortDefinitions: long, thin strand of cotton, nylon, or other fibres used in sewing

definitions: cotton, nylon, or other fibers spun into long, thin strands and used for sewing

examples.text: she put her needle and thread away

shortDefinitions: cotton, nylon, or other fibres spun

definitions: a long, thin line or piece of something

examples.text: the river was a thread of silver below them

shortDefinitions: long, thin line or piece of something

definitions: a theme or characteristic, typically forming one of several, running throughout a situation or piece of writing

examples.text: a common thread running through the scandals was the failure to conduct audits

shortDefinitions: theme or characteristic running throughout situation or piece of writing

definitions: (in online communication) a sequence of linked posts or messages.
shortDefinitions: sequence of linked posts or messages

definitions: a programming structure or process formed by linking a number of separate elements or subroutines, especially each of the tasks executed concurrently in multithreading.
a helical ridge on the outside of a screw, bolt, etc. or on the inside of a cylindrical hole, to allow two parts to be screwed together.
shortDefinitions: helical ridge on outside of screw, bolt, etc. or on inside of cylindrical hole

examples.text: his fine threads and fashionable specs

definitions: pass a thread through the eye of (a needle) or through the needle and guides of (a sewing machine)

examples.text: I can't even thread a needle
she threaded up the machine with the right cotton

shortDefinitions: pass thread through eye of needle or through needle and guides

definitions: pass (a long, thin object or piece of material) through something and into the required position for use

examples.text: he threaded the rope through a pulley

shortDefinitions: pass through something and into required position for use

definitions: put (something) on a thread, chain, etc. that passes through it, especially in such a way as to connect a number of things by passing a thread through each

examples.text: thread the buttons onto a length of cotton

shortDefinitions: put beads or other small objects on thread

definitions: move carefully or skillfully in and out of obstacles

examples.text: she threaded her way through the tables

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of direction

shortDefinitions: move carefully or skilfully in and out of obstacles

definitions: interweave or intersperse as if with threads

examples.text: his hair had become ill-kempt and threaded with gray

shortDefinitions: interweave or intersperse as if with threads

definitions: pluck hairs from (the eyebrows or another part of the body) using a twisted cotton thread

examples.text: I had my eyebrows threaded today

shortDefinitions: pluck hair using twisted cotton thread

definitions: cut a screw thread in or on (a hole, screw, bolt, etc.)

examples.text: we're laser-cutting holes to be threaded for screws

shortDefinitions: cut screw thread in or on
